item.title: Couple therapy or love in the storm
item.description: Now I work as a couple therapist, a dream that has long wanted to realize. My understanding is no longer based only on countless readings, but also on direct experience with the conflict of couples. I leave that these experiences resonate in my knowledge and my therapeutic practice, in the hope that they result in richer reflections in this space of writing. Today I want to tell you about love in the storm. A love relationship presupposes an affective bond. We can discuss the many possible forms of “couple”, but I invite you to focus on the idea of ​​two people who find themselves and seek to connect through what they are in the most intimate and deep. Usually, in this kind of relationship, there is sex - the mechanism of connection par excellence, which brings us to our most primary desires. Theory suggests that we choose our partners because they fit the long history of our affective connections, starting with the most primary relationships, such as our parents. Thus, we establish romantic bonds that, while offering the possibility of emotional reparation, also feed our dysfunctions. Love does not exist without this polarity. The bond lives in the tension between finding the love of our lives and the risk of this same love becoming in our greatest enemy. This is, of course, a caricature, but I want them to be aware of this duality. It is common for couples, when they become aware of this tension, seek therapy. Then comes an distressing question: How can the person who love to awaken me so much sadness, anger or frustration? It is the very evolution of the relationship that leads to these winding paths. Our beliefs, the way they shape our behavior and even our understanding of romantic love influence the way we deal with this ambivalence. The truth is that we have prepared little for this reality. Recently, a husband in deep anguish shared with me: “I didn't betray, nor walk behind anyone. I don't realize why we are like this. ” In couple therapy, the goal is not to eliminate the conflict, but to understand it. The mismatch is inevitable, which is why tools are sought to better deal with it. One of the pillars of this process is to create a space where one can talk frankly about the challenges of the relationship. However, this mismatch is emotionally charged and not always easy to resolve. It is not enough to offer a new map for the couple to follow a different path. It is not even the therapist's role to give simple solutions. To reconstruct a relationship, it is necessary to face a storm - uncontrolled rainwater, wind at 100 km/h and deafening thunder. The therapist helps navigate this storm so that the couple understands that love contains in itself this disruptive possibility. Deep down, the therapist confirms that even if suffering seems atrocious and the confusing mismatch, it's okay. The mismatch is part of life. The storm is a symptom of a primitive state, a reflex of the body in the face of the frustration of their emotional needs - they are proximity or removal. It is a state in which rational thinking is overshadowed by instinctive reaction. It can manifest itself as a struggle or escape, as if the partner were a predator, or as avoidance, an attempt to protect himself from a partner who seems to consume the little emotional energy that remains. Ultimately, the way we react to mismatch is linked to the way we deal with the affective bond. Regardless of the therapeutic approach used, all psychotherapeutic schools converge on this essential strategy: to make these internal mechanisms obvious. From this awareness, therapy helps the couple create new emotional "dances", promoting understanding and empathy to make the mismatch less destructive. Of course, there are couples who come to therapy at a point where the therapeutic space serves to prepare divorce or separation. In such cases, the mediation offered by the therapist allows them to maintain forms of communication based on respect. Many therapists “divorce” couples, and this is also a successful result. The stigma associated with therapy in general is a barrier. Apart from the sporadic romantic dinner, or quality time together, which many therapists will surely prescribe, therapy aims to go to other sites. Investing in relationship is essential for love, either through therapy or honest conversations about the couple's dynamics. Because love does not simply happen, it survives between comfort, pleasure and conflict.

item.title: Geogostronomy and the role of Portuguese cuisine in Macau
item.description: (continuation) Kitchen chiefs are increasingly experiencing melting dishes that incorporate international flavors, remaining faithful to Portuguese roots. The emergence of new gastronomic trends, such as “farm-to-table” and sustainable cuisine, reflects the growing awareness of the origin and quality of food. Social networks have also transformed the way culinary experiences are shared and perceived. Platforms like Instagram have made it easier for bosses to show their dishes to a global audience, attracting food enthusiasts and contributing to the promotion of macanese cuisine. Through visually appealing presentations, bosses may involve customers and encourage the appreciation of intricate flavors of Luso-Macaense cuisine. Several academic analyzes of Macau's geogostronomic landscape reveal the complex interaction between culture and food. Scholars emphasize the concept of identity, illustrating how culinary practices reflect the cultural heritage and values ​​of the community. The mix of Portuguese and Chinese culinary traditions creates a distinct identity for Macao, reinforcing its position as a cultural cauldron. The investigation suggests that gastronomic experiences are vital to fostering a sense of belonging among residents and promoting community ties. The culinary events and festivals that celebrate Luso-Macaense gastronomy further reinforce the community's involvement and promote a shared cultural identity, encouraging pride in local traditions and values. The role of Portuguese cuisine in Macau is ready for continuous evolution. The growing awareness of consumers for sustainability and health will probably shape culinary trends. Kitchen heads may prioritize the use of local and organic ingredients, while exploring innovative cooking techniques that honor traditional practices. Promoting educational programs that emphasize the importance of culinary heritage can help ensure that future generations enjoy and continue the tradition of Portuguese gastronomy. By promoting connections between chefs and consumers, Macau can maintain his unique cuisine in a constantly changing global landscape. The role of Portuguese gastronomy in Macau serves as a rich example of how cultural and geographical factors intertwine to shape culinary practices. As Macau sails for contemporary influences and anticipates future developments, the essence of Portuguese cuisine continues to prosper and evolve, promising a vibrant and dynamic culinary future. The evolution of macanese culinary culture is also influenced by the change in consumer habits and globalization. The increase in gastronomic tourism in Macao led to a greater interest in traditional dishes, as visitors eager for experiencing local flavors exploit the gastronomic landscape. Restaurants can respond by raising traditional recipes to exquisite gastronomic experiences. Events such as the “International Festival of Cities of Gastronomy, Macao” also promotes the appreciation for local cuisine, drawing attention to the skills of local bosses and the importance of culinary heritage. In recent years, conscious effort has been assisted to preserve traditional methods, simultaneously integrating modern techniques and global influences. The introduction of elements such as molecular gastronomy begins to be a practice in various luxury restaurants in Macao, creating a new dialogue between traditional dishes and contemporary food science. Estas abordagens inovadoras desafiam a noção de autenticidade, sugerindo que a tradição não é estática, mas dinâmica. While there are purists who advocate the preservation of original revenues, others advocate a reinterpretation that reflects contemporary food and preferences. The sustainability of Macanese cuisine in the modern context is another critical area to examine. Environmental awareness began to influence culinary practices, with an increasing emphasis on the use of local ingredients. This change improves the freshness of foods served in Macanese restaurants. Establishments are increasingly highlighting their commitment to ecological practices and can integrate in their sustainable seafood menus and organic vegetables. These practices ensure that although the kitchen remains rooted in its historical context, it continues to evolve in a sustainable way. In addition, the intersection of global trends had an impact on Macao's traditional culinary landscape. The global fascination with the melting kitchen encouraged bosses to experience unconventional combinations. This mixture of culinary traditions can be seen in the popularity of dishes such as the Macaense-Taieman lobster curry or almond cookies influenced by Portuguese and Chinese pastry techniques. These developments reflect the evolution of the taste of both local inhabitants and tourists, reflecting a broader culinary narrative that challenges traditional concepts of what constitutes macanese food. The future of Macanese cuisine seems promising, characterized by continuous exploration of identity, innovation and cultural exchange. As the culinary scene evolves, it is crucial that chiefs and gastronomy enthusiasts find a balance between respect for traditional methods and the adoption of new techniques. The potential for greater international recognition remains strong, particularly in the field of exquisite restoration, where macanese flavors can be presented with modern interpretations. However, challenges persist, namely as regards the preservation of authentic culinary practices. Discussions may arise around cultural appropriation as macanese dishes gain popularity and are adapted to various culinary contexts. The challenge lies in ensuring the maintenance of the integrity of traditional dishes and, at the same time, interacting effectively with a global audience. This dialogue enhances the delicate balance between adaptation and authenticity in culinary heritage. Macau's Portuguese cuisine represents a rich tapestry of flavors formed through centuries of cultural exchange, innovation and adaptation. The historical context provides a basis for understanding how these diverse influences intertwined, leading to a distinct culinary identity. Influential heads have defended this kitchen, ensuring its relevance in modern gastronomy, while sustainability efforts aim to keep it linked to local traditions. The interaction between tradition and modernity, authenticity and innovation will continue to shape the future of Macanese cuisine. The enthusiasm surrounding this culinary landscape promises to attract global interest, immortalizing the flavors and narratives that define this unique gastronomic heritage.

item.title: Improve the economy of Macau (i)
item.description: After Sam Hou Fai took office as the Chief Executive of Macao, he repeatedly expressed the desire to improve the region's economy, promoting moderate sector diversification and correcting the situation that leads to the game industry to master the city's economy. Macao has positioned itself as a leisure city, but its tourist model is changing 'traditional sightseeing' to 'immersive tourism' and there are many closed stores on the city streets. According to data from the Directorate of Statistics and Census Services, there were 42,996 industrial and commercial spaces closed in June 2020. In December 2024, this number rose to 43,343. These data show that the economy has not yet completely recovered after the pandemic and that the work of the Macao government at the level of economic development has become difficult. To stimulate the vitality of Macao's economy and benefit more residents of the city, several people argue that tourism should focus on the community rather than forwarding visitors to tourist attractions. Thus, the sales of stores in community areas can be increased, allowing more people to have access to tourism revenues and reducing the number of closed commercial spaces. Already part of this plan is the increase in the number of check-in points on Fulong Street and the appearance of many stalls in Coloane who sell top of gamma products. But how can we lead tourists to consume in the community? Some say that this objective can be achieved through concerts. The process would organize free transportation to take people who visit community tourist locations to the concert room. One of the reasons why Macau can successfully host these events is the fact that Hong Kong concert halls are always full. Macau can take the opportunity and provide alternative places. The concerts attract crowds so they are a great way to bring many tourists to Macau. Currently, some travel platforms, in collaboration with concert organizers, sell tickets, in packages that include stay at the hotel, meals, transportation and other items. The package is cheaper than if purchases were made individually. This model reduces the cost of travel to Macau and can increase tourists the desire to consume in the city. If the project is enriched with tourist bus services to allow visitors to access directly to tourist sites in the community areas, naturally the possibility of consuming local commerce will increase and this will be a way to stimulate Macao's economy. To achieve this goal, first it is necessary to ensure the success of the concert. Organizers have to sign a contract with the artists. But if there is more than an artist acting, you need to be very careful. The case that occurred with Messi, which was supposed to have played in Hong Kong, but ended up not playing, made the Raehk government have noticed that besides making a contract with a team, if they do not make individual contracts with all participants, the coming of some of them can be endangered. Messi's episode inspired Macau. When a concert is organized, in order to make sure that the fears that call more public will be present, it is necessary to sign separate contracts to ensure the presence of them all. Without this provisions, there is a possibility that some of these stars fail the concert. After ensuring the presence of the star, the next step is the transportation organization for viewers. Should this bus be a traditional tourist bus? Due to the current tendency of immersive travels, tourists apparently prefer normal buses to experience the city's daily life. Perhaps the society of Macao may have this innovative idea, that is, to use the macao public transport buses to perform this tourist service. These vehicles would take visitors to community tourist sites and could transport local tourists and residents. In this way, tourists would not only have the feeling of traveling in a vulgar bus, but the number of tourists who expect in transportation and congested local buses would also be reduced. And this should be taken into account because tourists carry luggage that takes up a lot of space. Tour buses would only travel between concert sites and community tourist areas. The number of passengers would be relatively low and each would have enough space, which increases comfort. The decision that these trips are paid or free must fit the carrier company. What will be the next step after guaranteeing concerts and tourist buses? Will tourists consume in community areas? We will give the answer next week. item.title: Photography | Known Sony World Photography Awards finalists
item.description: The finalists of the new edition of the Sony World Photography Awards are already known, considered the most prestigious awards in the sector. The distinctions, including in the “Photographer of the Year” category, will be known on April 16 at a ceremony in London. According to a statement, the “photographic projects were recognized by the technical domain and an original approach to the narrative”, being the finalists presented in an exhibition at Somerset House, patent from April 17 to May 5 this year. There are thus 30 finalists in this 18th edition, of which will result in ten winners, and more than 419 thousand images from over 200 countries and regions were subjected to contest. One of the highlights of this edition of Awards is the creation of a new category, the “Japan Professional Prize”, which highlights “the creativity and dynamism of the contemporary photographic scene of Japan” and “recognizes a winner and a restricted list of impressive series of Japanese photographers”. item.title: IC accepts applications for film and television financing
item.description:
The Cultural Institute (IC) accepts applications by the end of this month for the first round of candidates for the “Macao Film and Television Subsidy Plan”, and this initiative for financing private projects will have four candidacy rounds. The objectives, according to a note from the IC, are "to promote the image of Macao, encourage outward teams for filming in Macau and increase the international prestige of masters through cinematic and television works." Projects will be accepted for competition driven by a foreign filming team that include filming in Macao not less than three days. Another of the conditions is that this project may not have had any part filmed in the territory "before the confirmed presentation date." In addition, “applications must be presented by local commercial entrepreneurs”, ie “production units in Macao whose activities must be related to film production and television”.
Up to two million Another of the rules of the contest is that during the financial support period the public display of the project should be completed, and "the duration of the same and the places of Macao that served as a scenario must comply with the requirements presented". Regarding subsidies, will be granted up to a maximum limit of 30 to 40 percent of the budgetary expenses designed for filming, in the maximum amount between 500 thousand and two million patacas. "The assessment will be made taking into account the effect of promotion on the image of Macau by the project, the scale of production and the popularity of channels of exhibition of the cinematic or television work", as well as "the level of participation of the Macao film and television sector." This Thursday will be organized a clarification session on this financing plan, from 15h, on the seventh floor of the Cheng Feng Shopping Center Building, where the fund for the development of IC culture is located.

item.title: Creative Macau | The Macao space exposed in “Framing a Future Past”
item.description:
The Creative Macau Gallery hosts, from the 20th of this month, the exhibition “Framing A Future Past 2018-2024”, curated by Sara Neves and works by Nelson Silva, photography; and João Nuno Marques, with drawing. Both architects, they expose, through images and drawings, the view of a city in constant urban and social mutation
It's called “Framing a Future Past” and it is the new exhibition that will arrive in the Creative Macau space from March 20th. With curated by Sara Neves, linked to the area of ​​architecture, this show reveals the views of two architects based in Macao over the territory they inhabit and which they chose as a home. Nelson Silva presents his images, João Nuno Marques his drawings. The idea is, according to a statement, to explore "the various layers of the built space of Macau". The exhibition, patent until April 17, shows how, in the territory, the feeling of impermanence is always present ”in Macau, with“ spaces, buildings and places that appear, transform and disappear ”. “Within this dynamic environment, the act of documenting the city becomes essential, with the aim of observing and capturing fleeting moments,” is also described by the same press release. “As interveners in the evolution of the city, architects are challenged to understand the essence of a place and to deal with issues and uncertainties about their future.” “Framing A Future Past” presents “visual chronicles” that have been produced in recent years, namely since 2018, “the result of a personal process of discovery of the city by these two architects,” without being created specifically for this exhibition. Diversity With this show, the public will be able to observe “The Diversity of Macao, with special focus on the elements that may soon be part of the city's past”, besides fostering “the dialogue between two different techniques, photography and drawing, around a common theme, space and time”. Fascinated by nature since young, Nelson is presented as a “dedicated architect and photographer”. Nelson studied architecture at the University of Minho and spent a transformative year in Trondheim, Norway, where he aroused his interest in travel and different cultures. In 2018, he moved to Macau, where he has been dedicated to architecture and photography. Nelson is a partner of LBA Architecture & Planning and has gained recognition for his photographic work, including 2nd place in the 2024 Macao Architectural Photography Contest. In the case of João Nuno Marques, his formation was at the Faculty of Architecture of the University of Porto (FAUP), having specialized in “Architectural Heritage” and “Cooperation and Habitability in Developing Countries”, among other postgraduates in the field of architecture. Its professional career accumulates periods in Portugal, Spain, Germany and Turkey, before settling in Macao in 2017. It has divided its activity between the exercise of architecture in different sectors and the academic aspect at the University of São José (USJ), as visiting academic. In addition, João Nuno Marques is part of the Curb - Center for Macao Architecture and Urbanism. In your case, the design is used "not only as part of the work process, but while in-situ the places where it goes, trying to capture its architectural and cultural dimensions." Regarding Sara Neves, curator of this show, has a master's degree training at the Faculty of Architecture of the University of Lisbon. In 2016, the team of the fourth edition of the Lisbon Architecture triennial, then moved to Macao then moved. The curator is also visiting academic at USJ, ministering the discipline “Of Macau and Hong Kong”. In 2023, Sara completed the course of curatorial practices and contemporary arts in Venice. During this period, he co-rode the exhibition “Broken in Three Places” with the works of Sophie Jung and Maeve Brennan at the “A Plus a” gallery in Venice.

item.title: Portuguese Bookstore | Work of photographer Chris Stowers presented Sunday
item.description:
Launched in January, “Shoot, Ask… and Run!” It is the portrait of the life of a British photographer and his adventures behind the lens. Presented next Sunday at the Portuguese Bookstore, with the presence of the author, the book was born of diaries held by Chris Stowers during his trips through Asia
The adventures of a photographer in various Asian countries in the 1990s is the motto of Chris Stowers's book, released in January. “Shoot, Ask… and Run!” It is the name of the work released next Sunday at the Portuguese Bookstore from 18h. The title of the book is born of advice to the British photographer at the beginning of his travels that turned out to be of great use in everyday life. According to the book's synopsis, Chris Stowers was "plagued by stormy, both personal and international forces," fled "from the Jakarta mafia through the Borneo jungles, attacked with tear gas by Shock Police in Manila and crossed a Soviet union in implosion." But the adventures didn't end there: Stowers was even kidnapped "by a group of strongly armed Serbian militias." Thus, in the pages of this book “Stowers paints a hard, humorous and very human picture of the life of the media in Asia - and not only - during the years of expansion of the early 1990s”. The photographer has also passed Hong Kong "in the last days of the empire and analog photography." The book is therefore a parade of memories of a man who traveled a lot in search of the unknown. “Nato and nomad observer, the question is: where is your home?”, He is also questioned in the synopsis. With the seal of Earnshaw Books, this book is the second of his series of travel memories published by the publisher. From England to the world Chris left England in 1987, just left the high school with a trip to Karachi, Pakistan. He never left Asia again, having lived ten years in Hong Kong before the transfer of sovereignty in 1997, working as a photographer for Asiaweek magazine. His love for photography began soon through living with photojournalists Freelance impoverished in Peshawar, Pakistan, devastated by war, where he was at The Frontier Post. Chris Stowers joined the prestigious Panos pictures in 1992. Photographic missions and the desire to travel took Chris to more than 70 countries to date, and their work appeared throughout all kinds of publications, including Time, Newsweek, The Economist, Forbes, BusinessWeek, National Geographic Traveller and The New York Times. The photographer also made numerous guides for “Insight Guides” and “Dorling Kindersley”, co-author of the “Insight Guide” travel book and host of various television travel documentaries.

item.title: GDP | Macao economy grew 8.8% in 2024
item.description:
Macao Gross Domestic Product grew 8.8 percent by 2024 compared to the previous year, supported by the increase in the game industry and internal demand. On the other hand, the government's expense descended 5.1 percent of 2023, with the end of consumer cards
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) reached, last year, 403.3 billion patacas, "equivalent to 86.4 percent of the economic volume of the year 2019," said the direction of statistics and censuses (DSEC) in a statement on Friday. The value of GDP at the end of last year represented an annual growth of 8.8 percent compared to 2023. "Exports of services and internal demand (including private consumer expense, government final consumer consumption and investment) grew 9.2 and 2.3 percent, respectively, in annual terms," ​​reads the same note. Regarding the growth of service exports, DSEC highlights the impetus given by the annual increase of 23.8 percent of the number of visitors entries in 2024. The determining factor for the positive evolution of GDP was the 21.8 percent increase in game service exports over last year. Growth that contrasted with annual descent of 6.1 percent of exports of other tourist services, "due to the basis of relatively high comparison of the year 2023". Still, in this chapter, the 2024 record represented a growth of 13 per 2019. The DSEC also mentioned that foreign trade in goods and exports and imports of goods fell last year, respectively, 14.5 and 7.6 percent, when a 2023 comparison. Also according to the data, private consumption increased by 4.9 percent, in annual terms, “thanks to the continuing recovery of economic activities and the uninterrupted labor market stability”. DSEC also revealed that “the GDP per capita, which measures the average value of the goods and services produced per person, was 587,922 patacas”, a value that represents a 7.6 percent increase compared to 2023. The other side In the opposite direction, the government's expense fell, in the period under analysis, 5.1 percent, after the end of economic support measures, launched to relieve the impact of the pandemic, with DSEC to highlight the consumption card rounds released by 2023. In the public sector, the investment in equipment rose 1.2 percent, compared to 2023, while the investment in construction fell 10 percent, “due to the completion of part of the large public works”, reads in the note. With regard to private, investment in equipment grew 31.1 percent and under construction rose 5.1 percent in annual terms. In the last quarter of 2024, Macau GDP increased 3.4 percent, compared to the same period of 2023. DSEC stressed that internal demand and exports of services had homologous additions of 2.8 and 2.1 percent, respectively. João Luz / Lusa

item.title: Economy | Unemployment drops to 1.6% historical minimum
item.description:
The unemployment rate in Macao fell to 1.6 percent between November and January, a historical minimum since data on unemployment began in 1992. Also the resident unemployment rate set a record in 2.1 percent
In the period between November and January, the unemployment rate went down to 1.6 percent, the lowest amount since DSEC began collecting data on unemployment in Macao in 1992, even before the transition from territory administration from Portugal to China. According to the Directorate of Statistics and Census Services (DSEC), after seven months in a row to round 1.7 percent, the indicator fell 0.1 percentage points compared to the previous period, between October and December. In a statement, the DSEC explained that the rate reduction is due to “mainly the Chinese New Year originating the reduction in the number of individuals looking for employment, which led to a decrease in the number of unemployed”. The casinos sector hired 900 more people between November and January, reaching a labor of 72,500, while the Grosso and Retail trade also hired 200 more people. Macao received in January nearly 3.65 million visitors, 27.4 percent than in the same month of 2024 and the second highest value ever, while the game's revenues fell 5.6 percent in annual terms. Reinforcements from abroad The underemployment numbers also fell, with the underemployed 700 people to a total of 5,000 between November and January, compared to the previous period, with the rate of discharge to fall slightly to 1.3 percent. DSEC indicates that most of the sub -employed during the period under analysis belonged to the branches “of real estate activities and services provided to companies”. Over the past three months, the unemployment rate has fallen to a historical minimum, despite the labor coming from abroad, including in the interior of China, increasing at almost 5,900 during the year 2024. According to data from the Public Security Police Corps, released by the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs on February 5, Macau employed more than 182,500 migrant workers at the end of December. A number still far from the maximum peak of 196,538, reached in late 2019, before the beginning of the Covid - 19 pandemic. In fact, the unemployment rate among the inhabitants with resident status fell even more, 0.2 percentage points compared to the previous period, between October and December, to 2.1 percent, a value that is also a historical minimum. Between November and January, the number of unemployed residents cried by about 500 to 6,200, the lowest value from 27 years ago. Since 1998, however, the population of Macau has increased by 61.5 percent to 686,600 in late September, according to the latest DSEC estimate.

item.title: Game | Revenues go up in February, after falling in January
item.description:
Despite the most positive numbers, with February revenues reaching 19.7 billion Patacas, the total revenues of January and February fell short of the expected by analysts
The game's recipes increased 6.8 percent in February, compared to the same month of 2024, rising after a homologous fall in January, was announced on Saturday. The casinos collected more than 19.7 billion patacas in February, according to data from the Game Inspection and Coordination Directorate (DICJ). A value that exceeded the expectations of analysts. In a statement released on Wednesday, the company Creditsights, which is part of the Fitch Financial notation Agency group, said it was not certain an increase in the revenue of territory casinos in February. In January, Macao casinos had raised less than 18.3 billion patacas, a 5.6 percent drop compared to the same period as 2024. But with the recovery in February, the game sector ended up ensuring the best start of the year since 2019 before the COVID - 19 pandemic. In the first two months of the year, Macao casinos registered total revenues of nearly 38 billion patacas, more 0.5 percent than in the same period of 2024. This amount represents 75.5 percent of the accumulated in the first two months of 2019. Scratch Still, the start of the year fell short of the expectations of analysts of the company JP Morgan Securities, who on January 20 predicted that the recipes of the game in Macao would rise up to 2 percent annually in January and February. February included much of the so -called Golden Week of the Lunar New Year, a high time for tourism in Macao. This period of holidays in mainland China, which varies depending on the lunar calendar, took place this year between January 28 and February 4. On January 17, the director of Macao Tourism Services, Maria Helena de Senna Fernandes, said she expected a daily average of 185,000 visitors during the 'Golden Week'. But, according to data from the Macao Public Security Police, between January 28 and February 4, they entered the Chinese semi -autonomous region, on average, more than 163,700 tourists per day. In total, nearly 1.31 million people visited Macau during the Lunar New Year's 'Gold Week', less 3.5 percent than in the same period of holidays last year. Macao closed 2024 with total game recipes of 226.8 billion patacas, 23.9 percent than in 2023, but only 73.2 percent of the registered in 2019, before the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Hotels | 1,25 million guests received in January
item.description: Macao hotels received more than 1.25 million guests in January, a 4.7 percent drop in annual terms, was announced yesterday. In January 2024, hotel establishments in the territory had set a new record by hosting more than 1.32 million guests, the highest number of the year. The fall in January this year is “to reduce the number of guests in 5-star hotels”, according to a statement released yesterday by the Directorate of Statistics and Census Services (DSEC). At the end of the month under analysis, there were 147 hotel establishments in Macau, six more than in the same period last year, to be available 43,000 rooms (- 7 percent), says DSEC. The average occupancy rate of the hotel room guest rooms in January, settled at 89.8 percent, rising 3.9 percentage points, in annual terms, is indicated in the same note. In 2024, Macao hotel establishments welcomed more than 14.4 million guests in 2024, establishing a new historical record. The previous record, 14.1 million guests, had been fixed in 2019, before the Covid-19 pandemic, in a year that Macao ended with only 38,300 rooms in 122 hotel establishments.

item.title: China /USA | Beijing warns that coercion is not the best way to deal with problems
item.description: The Chinese government has warned Friday that it pressures and coercing "it is not the best way to deal with China," after Washington has announced that it will duplicate 20 percent additional customs rates on Chinese products. "China regrets and opposes this decision and will do everything it deems necessary to defend its legitimate interests," the Ministry of Foreign Ministry spokesman Lin Jian told a press conference. Lin said unilateral rates impair both the World Trade Organization and international trade relations and insisted that "there are no winners in commercial wars." Considering the fentanil “an internal problem of the United States,” Chinese diplomacy spokesman said Washington is using his opioid crisis to “press and coerce” China, although the Asian country is “one of the hardest” in the fight against the drug. The diplomat also stressed that Beijing has supported the US in his response to the Fentanil problem, transnational cooperation with results he described as "very remarkable." The diplomat urged Washington to address the problems "through dialogue and on an equality" and reiterated that China is willing to continue to cooperate with the US to achieve a "solid, stable and healthy" relationship. The conviction of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs follows to that of the Ministry of Commerce, which stated hours before China will take "all necessary countermeasures" to "defend its rights and legitimate interests." United States President Donald Trump promised on Thursday that his country would impose an additional 10 percent rate on China to join the other rate at the same value previously announced, with the argument that the Asian country made enough efforts to combat Fentanil entry in the US.

item.title: AVIC | Largest amphibian plane in the world concludes flight certification tests
item.description: The world's largest amphibious aircraft, the Ag600, completed all the flight tests needed to obtain aircraft certification, aviation industry corporation of China (AVIC). The Ag600, also the first large amphibian plane built in China, measures 39.6 meters long and 38.8 meters of wingspan, a size similar to that of a Boeing 737, and has a maximum weight of 53.5 tons. An amphibious plane is a model capable of peeling and landing on land and water. The plane, which was designed mainly for maritime rescue and fire -fighting missions, completed the latest flight tests in Shaanxi province in northwest China, Avic said, one of the country's state aircraft manufacturers in a statement. Over the past two years, the AG600 has completed 3,560 hours of flight in preparation for aircraft certification, the Chinese state consortium added. Flight tests were performed in a wide range of scenarios, including extreme cold, high temperatures and moisture and strong winds to verify the operational capabilities of the aircraft. The Ag600 is the largest amphibian aircraft currently in operation, comparable to scale to narrow fuselage aircraft such as Boeing 737 or Airbus A320. The first takeover of the aircraft took place on December 24, 2017, followed by another successful flight in 2018. In June 2024, China began the small scale production of the aircraft.

item.title: Africa | Cut in US support opens space to Chinese influence
item.description: Washington's decision to cut into external support offers China an opportunity to increase the influence in Africa, an analyst told Lusa, setting a parallel with donations made during the pandemic. The government led by Donald Trump confirmed this week that it will eliminate more than 90 percent of US Agency for International Development Agency (USAID) and $ 60 billion in general assistance around the world. In Africa, the cuts should have a particularly serious impact on health, which occupies the largest share of US support to the continent. Similar to what happened during the COVID-19 pandemic, experts expect China to fill the void left by Washington again. “Among African leaders, China has already built significant influence. Now it has the opportunity to seduce public opinion, ”explained Paul Natulya, a researcher at the African Center for Strategic Studies, a US Department of Defense Institute and funded by the US Congress. The US provides more than a quarter of all development aid on the African continent. An analysis performed by Denver's International Futures concluded that cuts can shoot another 5.7 million Africans below the $ 2.15 extreme poverty per day next year. During Trump's first term, which coincided with the Covid-19 pandemic, Africa became the region that most benefited from Chinese vaccine donations, testing, masks or fans, while Washington diminished his contributions and withdrew from the World Health Organization. "When the West retained donations of vaccines and medical equipment, China quickly filled the void," Natulya recalled. "In return, they received a lot of publicity and prestige, for a relatively small investment," he noted. Ranking in the ranking Different surveys now show that China has surpassed the United States in the popularity rate among African public opinion. According to an international poll from the Gallup Association, Beijing's approval among Africans went from 52 percent in 2022 to 58 percent in 2023, while Washington's popularity fell from 59 percent to 56 percent in the same period. Inquiries conducted by other institutes, such as Afrobarometer and Ichikowitz Family Foundation, demonstrate the same trend. "China is using all the tools at its disposal to gain this competitive advantage in the face of the United States," the researcher described. "At this time, I bet that, in Beijing, employees are studying the next step and when and how to increase China's contribution," he said.

item.title: Diplomacy | Xi says Beijing and Moscow should reinforce international coordination
item.description:
The Chinese president reaffirms the union between the two neighbors in the face of changes in the international scenario
Chinese leader Xi Jinping said China and Russia should continue to reinforce coordination in international matters and that both countries are “true friends,” Chinese state press has advanced on Saturday. Xi spoke at a meeting with Russian Security Council Secretary Sergei Shoigu, in Beijing, on Friday. Chinese head of state said Beijing and Moscow will implement in 2025 "a series of important agendas" and also requested the maintenance of "close communication at all levels." Xi recalled that he spoke twice this year with Russian homologist Vladimir Putin, the last of which this week. The Chinese leader also appealed to the maximization of the role of the BRICS Emerging Economies Group and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, two blocks of which China and Russia are members. Shoigu said Russia “greatly appreciates China's continuous efforts to promote peaceful resolution for the Ukrainian crisis,” but Chinese press did not indicate whether Xi made any mention of the peace process in Ukraine. The statements were published hours after a verbal confrontation in the White House between Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, and US homologist Donald Trump. According to the Xinhua official news agency, the Russian envoy said that the alliance between China and Russia "plays a significant role in the world and is a model for power relations." Shoigu also said that the relationship between the two countries "does not aim for third parties." Reinforced ties Before meeting Xi, Shoigu maintained talks with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, said the Russian Official Agency Tass. “Russia and China have coherent approaches to major international and regional problems,” said Shoigu, according to a video posted by Tass. Shoigu said he moved to Beijing “at the request of Russian President Vladimir Putin, following his telephone conversation with Chinese President Xi Jinping” without further details. "The fact that we have managed to organize our meeting within such a short term demonstrates the special nature of bilateral dialogue," said Sergei. The visit of the former Russian Defense Minister comes after a conversation between Xi and Putin on Monday during which the Chinese leader praised Moscow's "positive efforts to disagree" the Ukrainian crisis. Moscow and Beijing have reinforced military and commercial ties since the beginning of the Russian offensive in Ukraine, although China seeks to present itself as a neutral in the three-year conflict. According to the Russian press, Shoigu "will discuss bilateral security issues, as well as international and regional problems, with high Chinese leaders."

item.title: Hong Kong | Secretary for Innovation looking for business in Portugal
item.description: Hong Kong's secretary for innovation, technology and industry will be on Thursday in Portugal to “explore business opportunities” for the innovation and technology sector, the Chinese region said yesterday. In a statement, the Hong Kong government said Sun Dong settled yesterday ahead of a delegation of innovation and technology representatives, which will be in Lisbon on March 6. The visit program includes “meetings and exchanges with leaders of local political, business and innovation and technology” as well as infrastructure visits, technological parks, research institutes and companies. The aim is to “reinforce ties and cooperation” with Portugal in this sector, “promoting the advantages of Hong Kong innovation and technology and exploring business opportunities abroad,” according to the statement. The delegation includes managers from three public institutions: HKSTP, a company created in 2001 to promote innovation and technological development in the region, the Institute of Research in Science and Technology Applied and the Institute of Research and Development of Microelectronics. In addition, they will be in Lisbon leaders of the Cyberport Technology Park, as well as representatives of 24 companies or Hong Kong innovation and technology institutions. Before passing through Lisbon, the Hong Kong delegation will be in Barcelona, ​​in northeastern Spain, to participate in Mobile World Congress, considered one of the most influential technological events worldwide. This will be the second visit to Portugal of a member of the Hong Kong government within a year, after the secretary for the region's financial and treasure services had passed through Lisbon in June. At the time, Christopher Hui Ching-Yu asked Portugal to remove Hong Kong from the list of tax havens and argued that it already fulfills European Union (EU) standards to combat fiscal dropout.

item.title: Japan | Worst fires since 1992 have been forced by two thousand people
item.description: About two thousand people had to abandon their dwellings in northern Japan, where forest fires have already burned the largest area since 1992 and did a dead, the Japanese authorities said yesterday. The Japanese disasters and fires response agency (FDMA) said the areas around the city of Ounato were evacuated in the Iwate Forest Region. Many took refuge with friends or family, and more than 1,200 were taken to shelters, added FDMA. At least one person died in the flames, which triggered on Wednesday, and also damaged over 80 buildings. "We are still trying to determine the affected area, but it is the largest since 1992," a FDMA spokesman said yesterday to the France-Presse news agency. In 1992, a fire destroyed 1,030 hectares in Kushiro, Hokkaido, in the north of the country. According to the Japanese press, the fire has already spread to 1,800 hectares. Aerial images of the Japanese public broadcaster NHK showed military helicopters to fly over white tobacco clouds, four days after the beginning of the fire. About 1,700 firefighters were mobilized across the country to try to extinguish the flames. The cause of the fire is not yet known, but it is believed to have started in a work shed and spread from there to a wooded zone, where dry meteorological conditions favored its propagation. This is the third fire in a week to affect the southern coastal areas of Iwate, which have been on alert for dry weather since February 18.

item.title: Japan | Births fall to a new negative record
item.description: The number of births in Japan fell to a new record, increasing the challenge related to increasing social security costs in an aging society, with an increasingly reduced group of workers who pay taxes. The number of newborns in 2024 fell 5 percent over the previous year to 720,988, extending a number of nine years of decline, according to preliminary data on the population released yesterday by the Japan Ministry of Health. This reading marks the lowest value since these records started in 1899. Also the deaths increased by 1.8 percent to a record of 1.62 million in the same period, resulting in the largest annual decline as always of the total population, according to the report. The sustained decline of births in the country increases the urgency felt by a government that is already supporting the heaviest debt among developed countries. Japan's public debt will be 232.7 percent of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) this year, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The demographic situation in Japan is in tune with a growing global trend. South Korea's fertility rate increased last year for the first time in nine years, but with 0.75, it is still far below the rate required to maintain the population. The fall in birth in France accelerated in 2023, reaching the fastest rhythm in half a century, while China's population decreased for three consecutive years. Fewer workers means fewer tax revenues for niponic state coffers, while pressuring companies, which face staff scarcity. Vain efforts Since Japan's active age population has reached their maximum in 1995, their labor market has been relatively tight. The unemployment rate is 2.4 percent, the lowest among OECD countries, and has been maintained below 3 percent for almost four years. By 2040, Japan is expected to face a labor deficit of 11 million people, according to an estimated Recruit Works Institute, quoted by Bloomberg. In 2024, a record number of 342 Japanese companies went bankrupt due to labor shortages, according to a teikoku Databank inquiry, according to the news agency. However, Japan's social security costs continue to increase as a growing proportion of the population exceeds the age of reform. For the fiscal year that begins in April, the government has attributed 37.7 billion of yen to social security, an increase of almost 20 percent over the last decade. Japan's pension system is also under pressure, with fewer contributors and more beneficiaries. Over the past two decades, the number of taxpayers has decreased by about 3 million, while the number of beneficiaries has increased by almost 40 percent, according to the Japanese Ministry of Social Security. The continuous decline in the number of births reflects, in part, the reluctance of younger generations to have children despite recent government efforts. Based on an initiative of his predecessor, Prime Minister Shigero Ishiba is promoting a package of child care policies worth 3.6 billion yen, which includes support for future parents and improvements in the working conditions of day care workers.

item.title: Xiaomi | Appreciation of actions make founder in the richest man in China
item.description: The 5.8 percent rise in the quotation of Chinese Xiaomi actions on Wednesday made the technology founder and executive director, Jun Law, in China's richest man, local press reported.
